intro: Mitrasacme scopata, commonly known as the hairy mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant that grows on various host trees in tropical regions. It belongs to the family Loranthaceae and is characterized by its small, leathery leaves and inconspicuous flowers. The plant derives some of its nutrients from its host through specialized structures called haustoria. It produces small, white or yellowish berries that are dispersed by birds. Due to its parasitic nature, it can have significant impacts on the health of its host trees.
